C I T Y OF C A M B R I DGE , M A S S A CH U S E T T S

PLANNING BOARD
C I T Y H A L L A NN E X , 3 4 4 B R O A D W A Y , C A MB R I D G E , M A 0 2 1 3 9

AGENDA
Tuesday, January 26, 2021 at 6:30 PM
Remote Meeting
Cambridge, Massachusetts
PLEASE NOTE: Due to statewide emergency orders limiting the size of public gatherings in response to COVID-19, this meeting will be held with
remote participation and closed to in-person attendance. Members of the public can view the meeting online or on cable television within
Cambridge, provide comments before the meeting to planningboardcomment@cambridgema.gov, and attend virtually online or by telephone.
Register for Zoom Webinar to participate in real time (before or during the meeting):
https://cambridgema.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_4ZgeJCklTHGq4dT5ulN0uA
Check your e-mail (including spam/junk folder) for confirmation.
If you do not have a computer or e-mail address, attend via phone:
Dial: 312-626-6799 or 929-436-2866 or 301-715-8592 or 346-248-7799 or 669-900-6833 or 253-215-8782
Webinar ID: 813 9545 3543
Review Information about Remote Planning Board Meetings:
www.cambridgema.gov/CDD/zoninganddevelopment/planningboard/remoteplanningboardmeetings
If you have questions about remote meetings, please call Swaathi Joseph at 617-349-4668.

General Business
Update from the Community Development Department

Public Hearings
6:30 p.m.
PB# 370
51 Vassar Street – Special Permit application by Massachusetts Institute of Technology to construct a
new building of approximately 174,000 square feet of mixed institutional and academic uses and
publicly accessible retail use pursuant to Section 19.20 Project Review Special Permit and Section 6.35.1
Reduction of Required Parking. (Materials)
7:30 p.m.
PB# 372
118 Holworthy Street – Special Permit application by 118 Holworthy St., Realty, LLC to construct a singlefamily residence greater than 75 feet from the front line and to the rear of an existing single family
residence pursuant to Section 5.53 – more than one structure on a lot in a Residence B district and
Section 8.22.2c – additional windows on an existing non-conforming facade. (Materials)

General Business items may be taken out of the order in which they appear on the agenda above. Times for General Business items
are approximate. Public comments are taken only during a Public Hearing. During the discussion and deliberation on General
Business items, the Planning Board does not solicit public comment. The City of Cambridge will provide reasonable accommodations
to people with disabilities upon request. Please make requests for alternative formats at least two weeks in advance by contacting
the Planning Board staff listed below. For further information concerning this agenda, please contact Swaathi Joseph, Planning Board
staff, at 617 349 4668, sjoseph@cambridgema.gov. Applications and Petitions are online at www.cambridgema.iqm2.com.

5 | MIT Stephen A. Schwarzman College of Computing – Cambridge Planning Board Presentation

Addressing the opportunities and challenges of the computing age — from hardware to
software to algorithms to artificial intelligence —
by transforming the capabilities of academia in three key areas:

Packet Pg. 48

#46

Communication: 51 Vassar St_20210126 (PB-370)

East Facade

48 | MIT Stephen A. Schwarzman College of Computing – Cambridge Planning Board Presentation
48

Packet Pg. 49

1. Thermal Insulation
In winter, the air cavity on the double skin facade is heated by the low angled
sun, providing an extra layer of thermal insulation, reducing the heating
energy load.

2. Transparency
The double skin facade offers a balance of high energy performance and
high transparency. The double skin performance is comparable to an
opaque, insulated wall while the high level of transparency offers building
occupants access to daylight and views, putting the life of the building on
display from the exterior.
3. Automatic Solar Control
The double skin cavity is equipped with automated roller shades tuned to
the exterior environment (sun position, cloud coverage, and season). The
shades improve visual comfort for occupants and reduce solar heat gain
loads on the interior.

49 | MIT Stephen A. Schwarzman College of Computing – Cambridge Planning Board Presentation

Packet Pg. 50

Communication: 51 Vassar St_20210126 (PB-370)

Sustainability
Façade Design

Sustainability
Project Sustainability Goals & Performance

•
•
•

LEED BD+C v4 Gold Certification
Design the building & site to be resilient to 2070 100-year storm & heat impacts
Reduce impervious area and manage storm water within our boundary, including an extensive green roof
Proposed design including a heat pump chiller; 49% reduction in energy and 63% reduction in GHG emissions over
LEED v4 baseline*
Reduce indoor potable water use 36.7% from EPA baseline
Track & report embodied carbon & construction GHG emissions
Material selection prioritizing Red List-free interior materials and targeting to be free of PVC, flame retardants and
PFAS chemicals

50 | MIT Stephen A. Schwarzman College of Computing – Cambridge Planning Board Presentation

Communication: 51 Vassar St_20210126 (PB-370)

•
